content:
By ignoring precedence you just trap coders who assume precedence matters in fastest mode.
What's worse is that you get 100% on all the test cases by assuming precedence matters, but then only get 40% on the validators!
You need to swap some test cases and validators if you want to keep it this way, but really it's dumb to ignore precedence when you claim to be explaining how these operators work.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a fun and simple challenge for Clash of code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A good small challenge

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and fun clash, good for coc !

Nice clash! Just a (noob) question: is & and | in all languages AND and OR? I only know Python so I can guess from '1 & 0 & | 1' what the idea is, but I do not know the term 'logical suit' (maybe also noob of me), so without the knowledge of & and | I would have no idea what to do.

I assume a 'logical suit' is whatever you give as input in this Clash. If so, you could alter the statement sentence "...the result of the <<logical suit>> given..." into "...the result of the <<logical suit>> (for example {{1 & 0 | 1}}) given ..." -- AND/OR you could change the input statement to "A [[string]] representing a logical suit of the form: {{1 & 0 | 1}}".

Your contribution has been uploaded twice. Please remove one of them. The other link is:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/52188bc9190cc09ee40daab88e3e7045a12a7

Also, binary output should be avoided for clashes based on the contribution guidelines. Please change the output requirement so that there are more than 2 possible answers in total.

Thanks.

What about precedence ?
You should compute the "&" before the "|" (but maybe too difficult for a clash ?) or at least write in the statement that you don't care about precedence.

Also, why not shortest mode ?
IMO, precedence isn't too difficult for a clash, but ....
I swapped a validator and test case to make this less annoying for now, but you should either get rid of the 'ignore precedence' thing or make it much clearer in the statement, imo.
I got this again as a clash just now and the statement was very confusing again. So I've now edited it to be much clearer, since the author seems to be inactive.

This is terrible.
By ignoring precedence you just trap coders who assume precedence matters in fastest mode.
What's worse is that you get 100% on all the test cases by assuming precedence matters, but then only get 40% on the validators!
You need to swap some test cases and validators if you want to keep it this way, but really it's dumb to ignore precedence when you claim to be explaining how these operators work.

I didn't notice that tests would pass with precedence and not validators.
It is also terrible for reverse mode. In fatest mode someone would say "it was in the statement".
I've just seen you inverted a test and a validator, good !
